I am very sad to read today that Senator Ted Kennedy, that great champion of human rights, has a malignant brain tumor. What a terrific Senator he has been, championing equal rights for gay people, for women, for African Americans, for the poor, for the disabled. I hope he can hang on a little longer, to enjoy a Democratic victory in November. I am holding him in the light, as the Quakers do. He has certainly been a supporter of gay people, as few others in the Senate have been.
jyoshu
Sad, but it's hard for me to look with admiration on someone who probably should have been in prison during all or a lot of nearly the last 40 years.
Steeeeve
I just hope he is one of the rare people that can recover. This kind of disease is no good and I never like to see folks suffer.
snakespit

Not real good news. I have never cared for the man, but I wouldn't wish that on anyone. Probably a glioblastoma or a malignant astrocytoma, which in either case is not good, especially the former. So far, I have only heard chemotherapy and radiation suggested, which leads one to believe that the doctors are probably considering it inoperable. An inoperable glioma is typically a death sentence. Most often the cause of death is a hemorrhagic stroke, as high grade gliomas are highly vascular and prone to aneurysm.
chester

Most often the cause of death is a hemorrhagic stroke, as high grade gliomas are highly vascular and prone to aneurysm.

 
 Two friends of mine were diagnosed with malignant brain tumors last year. One had an astrocytoma, and her tumor was inoperable. She died 7 months after her diagnosis. My other friend was diagnosed with a glioblastoma multiforme, and she had surgery followed by radiation and chemotherapy. She is doing well and is returning to work this fall. The prognosis for this kind of cancer is grim, but so far she is doing okay.

 The difference = Time to sober up.

Two friends of mine were diagnosed with malignant brain tumors last year. One had an astrocytoma, and her tumor was inoperable. She died 7 months after her diagnosis. My other friend was diagnosed with a glioblastoma multiforme, and she had surgery followed by radiation and chemotherapy. She is doing well and is returning to work this fall. The prognosis for this kind of cancer is grim, but so far she is doing okay.

 
 Then your friend is by far the exception vs. the rule...good for her! I should temper that by saying that in most cases, it will return...just a matter of time. A few people win, most lose. My wife is an oncology nurse and was telling me first hand tonight that she cannot remember more than a few out of several hundred that beat it. It is not impossible for Teddy to beat this thing...but in all probability, it is highly unlikely that he will. Seizures are typically a late sign of a fast growing tumor. This typically is when the doc will tell you not to buy any green bananas. I hope I am wrong.
 
 At the same time...I hope Teddy never comes back to the senate. He scares me politically about as much as Pelosi and her merry bunch of XXXXXX.

Ohioprof

I think discussion of Ted Kennedy has to do with gay rights because he has been one of the strongest supporters in American politics of equality and fairness. While some others have tried to please both sides by claiming to be for gay rights but against same-sex marriage, Ted Kennedy has supported the right of same-sex couples to get married, period. Here is a quote from a 2005 address by Ted Kennedy to the National Press Club on a progressive vision for America: 
 
 http://www.commondreams.org/views05/0112-37.htm
 
 "On the issue of gay rights, I continue to strongly support civil marriage. We cannot - and should not - require any religion or any church to accept gay marriage. But it is wrong for our civil laws to deny any American the basic right to be part of a family, to have loved ones with whom to build a future and share life's joys and tears, and to be free from the stain of bigotry and discrimination."
 
 Ted Kennedy has been better on gay rights than has either Barack Obama or Hillary Clinton. Losing him will be a terrible blow for those of us who share his vision.
lesz

I can understand feelings of sadness and dismay over the coming loss of Kennedy -- an era draws to a close. On the other hand, the old trees have to go if the younger ones are to flourish, and arguably, Kennedy was inhibiting the growth of new liberals through his own domination of the party. Times move on, but old pols seldom move with them. Democrats need some new blood in their veins. If y'all will forgive me the mix of metaphors...
